perturbation.original_text: (n)	“Arizona Trademark License Term” means the period commencing on the Effective Date and ending twenty-four (24) months thereafter.
perturbation.changed_text: (n)	“Arizona Trademark License Term” means the period commencing on the Effective Date and ending twenty-four (24) months thereafter, unless otherwise terminated as per section 12. The period may be extended by mutual agreement in writing for successive one-year terms.
perturbation.explanation: The original text defines the Arizona Trademark License Term as a fixed 24-month period. The changed text introduces an extension clause, creating a contradiction. It's now unclear whether the term is strictly 24 months or potentially longer, leading to uncertainty in enforcement regarding trademark usage rights beyond the initial term.

perturbation.original_text: 6.5	Trade Names. The Company shall not create or use any corporate or trade names that include the Arizona Licensed Trademarks, other than those in existence immediately prior to the Effective Date. No later than thirty (30) days following the Closing, each of AWP and the Company shall change its respective corporate name and trade name and cause its organizational documents to be amended to remove any reference to “Armstrong.”
perturbation.changed_text: 6.5	Trade Names. The Company shall not create or use any corporate or trade names that include the Arizona Licensed Trademarks, other than those in existence immediately prior to the Effective Date. Each of AWP and the Company shall use commercially reasonable efforts to change its respective corporate name and trade name and cause its organizational documents to be amended to remove any reference to “Armstrong” within a commercially reasonable timeframe, not to exceed one hundred and eighty (180) days.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a strict 30-day deadline for changing corporate names. The changed text replaces this with a 'commercially reasonable timeframe, not to exceed one hundred and eighty (180) days' standard. This introduces a contradiction by allowing for flexibility in the deadline, creating uncertainty and potential disputes regarding compliance with the original 30-day requirement.

perturbation.original_text:
12.1	Term and Termination.
(a)	Unless earlier terminated pursuant to the provisions hereof, the term of this Agreement and the licenses and other grants of rights (and related obligations) under this Agreement shall (i) with respect to the Arizona Licensed Trademarks, be for the Arizona Trademark License Term, (ii) with respect to the Diamond Licensed Trademarks, be for the Diamond Trademark License Term, (iii) with respect to the Phase-Out Marks, be for the term set forth in Section 6.6, and (iv) with respect to Copyrights, Know-How and Patents, be in perpetuity.
perturbation.changed_text:
12.1	Term and Termination.
(a)	Unless earlier terminated pursuant to the provisions hereof, the term of this Agreement and the licenses and other grants of rights (and related obligations) under this Agreement shall (i) with respect to the Arizona Licensed Trademarks, be for the Arizona Trademark License Term, unless extended by mutual written agreement of the parties, (ii) with respect to the Diamond Licensed Trademarks, be for the Diamond Trademark License Term, subject to earlier termination as outlined in section 12.1(b), (iii) with respect to the Phase-Out Marks, be for the term set forth in Section 6.6, and (iv) with respect to Copyrights, Know-How and Patents, be in perpetuity, except in cases of gross negligence.
perturbation.explanation: The original text establishes fixed terms for the Arizona and Diamond Licensed Trademarks and perpetuity for Copyrights, Know-How and Patents. The modified text introduces exceptions: the Arizona Trademark License Term can be extended, the Diamond Trademark License Term can be terminated earlier, and the licenses to Copyrights, Know-How and Patents can be terminated in cases of gross negligence. This creates contradictions regarding the duration and irrevocability of the licenses, leading to uncertainty in enforcement.
